newsitem.title: SWEDEN: German freighter aground off Iceland, one missing.
newsitem.headline: German freighter aground off Iceland, one missing.

text.p: A German container ship was on Thursday in danger of breaking up and leaking bunker oil after it ran aground off the coast of Iceland in heavy seas, leaving one rescue-crew member missing, an Icelandic coast guard official said.
An attempt by a local coast guard vessel to tow the freighter ashore failed, and one Icelandic crew member went overboard in the process, the official said.
The body had not yet been recovered.
All 19 of the German crew were safe after being rescued from the ship by helicopter, the official added.

"It (the vessel) is now aground in very bad weather and listing 40 percent. There is considerable visible damage to the ship -- it is breaking apart," the official, who asked not to be named, told Reuters by telephone from Reykjavik.

The 8,000-tonne Vikartindur went aground at 1947 GMT on Wednesday about 1.5 miles from the Icelandic coast after being struck by a heavy wave. It had been drifting for about two hours because of engine trouble.
The ship was leased by Iceland's largest shipping company Eimskip, the official said. The ship was owned by a major German shipping company, he said, but gave no details.
The ship was carrying cargo, all of which was in containers, from Germany to Iceland, the official said.
"The owners, insurance companies and rescue teams are at the site and looking for ways to minimise the loss," he said.
A small amount of the 350 tonnes of heavy oil on board the ship had begun to leak, and more pollution was feared.
No one could board the ship because of the bad weather, freezing temperatures and gales measuring 40 to 70 knots.
